title: How to Solve a Rubik's Cube in 20 Moves

steps.title: Give the cube’s top layer a single clockwise turn.
steps.content: Give the cube’s top layer a single clockwise turn. Start from an already-solved cube (as they usually are when they come out of the package) or one that is already mixed up. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Spin the right layer 2 times clockwise.
steps.content: Spin the right layer 2 times clockwise. When solving a Rubik’s Cube, the directions (right, left, front, back) are relative to how you hold the cube. So, “right” means whatever layer is currently on the right side of the front of the cube.

steps.title: Turn the front side (the side currently facing you) clockwise once.
steps.content: Turn the front side (the side currently facing you) clockwise once.

steps.title: Rotate the back side once clockwise.
steps.content: Rotate the back side once clockwise. The back side is whichever layer is opposite the front.

steps.title: Give the right side of the cube 1 clockwise turn.
steps.content: Give the right side of the cube 1 clockwise turn.

steps.title: Spin the back layer 2 times clockwise.
steps.content: Spin the back layer 2 times clockwise. Ensure the "back" layer stays the back throughout the process rather than turning the entire cube to make a move. It’s easier to stay oriented when the cube faces the same direction the whole time.

steps.title: Rotate the right side of the cube once clockwise.
steps.content: Rotate the right side of the cube once clockwise.

steps.title: Give the top layer of the Rubik’s Cube 2 clockwise turns.
steps.content: Give the top layer of the Rubik’s Cube 2 clockwise turns.

steps.title: Turn the left side of the Rubik’s Cube once clockwise.
steps.content: Turn the left side of the Rubik’s Cube once clockwise. This is whichever side is opposite the right from where you’re holding the cube.

steps.title: Spin the cube’s back layer 2 times clockwise.
steps.content: Spin the cube’s back layer 2 times clockwise.

steps.title: Rotate the right side of the cube once clockwise.
steps.content: Rotate the right side of the cube once clockwise.

steps.title: Give the top side a single counterclockwise spin.
steps.content: Give the top side a single counterclockwise spin.

steps.title: Turn the bottom layer (the side opposite the top) once counterclockwise.
steps.content: Turn the bottom layer (the side opposite the top) once counterclockwise.

steps.title: Rotate the right side once again with 2 clockwise spins.
steps.content: Rotate the right side once again with 2 clockwise spins.

steps.title: Spin the front side of the cube once clockwise.
steps.content: Spin the front side of the cube once clockwise. By this point, you’ll notice that the colors on each side of the cube are starting to match up!

steps.title: Give the cube’s right side a single counterclockwise spin.
steps.content: Give the cube’s right side a single counterclockwise spin.

steps.title: Turn the left layer clockwise once again.
steps.content: Turn the left layer clockwise once again.

steps.title: Give the back layer of the cube 2 clockwise turns.
steps.content: Give the back layer of the cube 2 clockwise turns.

steps.title: Rotate the cube’s top layer with 2 clockwise spins.
steps.content: Rotate the cube’s top layer with 2 clockwise spins.

steps.title: Finish your Rubik’s Cube by giving the front side 2 clockwise turns.
steps.content: Finish your Rubik’s Cube by giving the front side 2 clockwise turns. With that, you’ve solved a Rubik’s Cube in 20 moves!

steps.title: Solve any 3x3 Rubik’s Cube using the Super-Flip method.
steps.content: Solve any 3x3 Rubik’s Cube using the Super-Flip method. The steps you followed above were from an algorithm called the “Super-Flip,” which solves the puzzle while flipping the position of each color when finished. There’s more than one way to solve a Rubik’s cube, but the Super-Flip allows you to solve it in exactly 20 steps! [2] X Research source

steps.title: Use “HTM” or “half-turn metric” with this Super-Flip algorithm.
steps.content: Use “HTM” or “half-turn metric” with this Super-Flip algorithm. There are also different metrics for solving Rubik’s Cubes, but the one you’ll need for this solution is HTM. With the half-turn metric, any turn of any face, by any angle, counts as 1 turn. [3] X Research source This metric is different from others mainly because “slice” moves (any turn of a middle layer on the cube) count as 2 turns, and half-turns count as 1 move.

steps.title: God’s Number is 20 when you use HTM to solve a Rubik’s Cube.
steps.content: God’s Number is 20 when you use HTM to solve a Rubik’s Cube. “God’s Number” is a term that refers to the greatest number of moves that a puzzle can be from its solved state. [4] X Research source So, when we say the number is 20 for HTM, it means that any Rubik’s Cube is 20 moves away from being solved while using the half-turn metric. [5] X Research source Keep in mind that God’s Number is only 20 for standard 3x3x3 Rubik’s Cubes. For others, God’s Number varies—and in some cases, it hasn’t been found yet.

steps.title: Memorize
steps.content: Memorize clockwise and counterclockwise by visualizing a clock. If you get confused about which way to turn your cube at any time, picture an analog clock's moving hands. “Clockwise” means turning in the same direction as a clock does, and “counterclockwise” means going in the opposite direction.

steps.title: Learn the solution algorithm in Singmaster notation.
steps.content: Learn the solution algorithm in Singmaster notation. Solution algorithms for the Rubik’s cube are often written in Singmaster notation, a code where each letter or symbol denotes a move on the Rubik’s Cube. The Singmaster code for the solution above is U R2 F B R B2 R U2 L B2 R U' D' R2 F R' L B2 U2 F2. [6] X Research source Here’s what that means: R (Right) : The side facing to the right. L (Left) : The side facing to the left. U (Up) : The side facing up on the cube. D (Down) : The side facing downwards. F (Front) : The side facing you. B (Back) : The side facing away from you. Apostrophes denote a counterclockwise turn, so a counterclockwise right spin is R’. 2 turns of the cube (or 180-degree spins) are denoted with “2,” so turning the left side twice would look like F2.
